div.p: With Master Martyr, I have advocated not for your cause, but for the cause of the Church of God. However, many things must be considered carefully and prudently; for if he departs, we are greatly concerned about succession. If it were permissible to assign the name of a certain little monk, whom our enemy has brought here, we are uncertain about what he intends to do; what he wants and where he aims, no one knows. Master Martyr also considers this. I received letters from Master Calvin and Beza, of which I would gladly send you a copy if I had the leisure to transcribe them. You would see the testimony of those churches and about him, whom they call impious, cruel, shameless, a sycophant, a manifest apostate. I will obey your advice and that of the brothers, as much as I can, and with God's help, I will erase this madness with eternal oblivion. However, I am uncertain how this will be done; for every day he continues, and now, when he sees that he has not been able to harm either my reputation or my fortunes, he is, as I hear, planning against my life. I do not dare to explain the matter to you more clearly, as you see what the time is. They say the King of France is to be feared diligently; the city is fortified; therefore, it will be guarded against the French. In this tumult, a little word can do more harm than the most verbose accusations at another time. God will have mercy on my family; moving would be most pleasing to me at this time, especially since my wife is about to give birth; but if my affairs in Paris were settled, that is, if my mother had responded, I would think it best to act as [Greek] or [Greek]. If I could be of any service to your church, about which I ask you to think, keep this to yourself. However, I earnestly ask you, as much as I can, if it pleases you to write to me, you would do me a great favor; but I beg you, not to anyone else.
My reverend and best father, farewell.
I would like you to greet Master Gessner and Master Gualter, most distinguished men, in my name.
To the most distinguished man, Master Heinrich Bullinger, outstanding minister of God and the Church of Zürich, most excellent theologian. In Zürich.
